frameset.note: Frames for MATCH as developed by Christiane Fellbaum and refined by Martha Palmer and Paul Kingsbury

roleset.name: match

example.name: basic transitive
example.text: The architect matched the paint and the wallpaper

example.name: with-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the paint with the wallpaper

example.name: inverted with-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the wallpaper with the paint

example.name: to-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the paint to the wallpaper

example.name: inverted to-phrase
example.text: The architect matched the wallpaper to the paint

example.name: unaccusative
example.text: The paint and the wallpaper matched

example.name: tricky
example.text: The company matched Kodak's higher prices.
example.note: The idea here is that the second Arg1 (presumably the company's prices) is unstated but fairly easily recoverable. This happens a lot in real usage.)

roleset.note: The matched items all have the same status as arguments/semantic roles.

There are passives
(6a) The paint is matched (by the wallpaper) (6b) The wallpaper is matched (by the paint)
but these are adjectival, not verbal, as the tests show:
The paint was unmatched The paint is well matched *At noon, the paint was matched my the wallpaper
Therefore, (6) are predicative sentences, and the participle is an adjective, just like "peeling." So the (optional) by-phrase is an adverbial; the noun in the by-phrase is not an A0 (agent) argument.
(6a) The paint is [matched (by the wallpaper)] AdjP (6b) The wallpaper is [matched (by the paint)] AdjP
(And therefore these cases are not to be tagged--Paul)
